questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents to the gynecology clinic seeking long-term contraception. She has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea.She has no significant medical history and is not currently taking any medications. After discussing various options, she is interested in intrauterine devices.Which of the following is the most appropriate intrauterine device (IUCD) for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of IUCD

Examples

Composition

MOA

Duration

Advantages

First Generation

Lippes loop

Non medicated made of polyethylene or other polymers
  • Leads to foreign body reaction producing sterile inflammatory responses

10 years
  • Long duration
  • double "S" shape closely fit the contours of the uterine cavity, reducing the chance of expulsion

Second Generation

 

(Copper IUCDs)

Copper T 380

Copper wire wrapped around the IUCD
  • Releases copper ions which are spermicidal
  • Impairs sperm motility and viability
  • Interfere with the capacitation of sperm

10-12 years
  • Long duration
  • No hormones involved
  • Suitable for those who cannot use hormonal contraception

Third Generation

 

(Hormonal IUCDs)
  • Mirena
  • Progestasert

Levonorgestrel
  • Releases levonorgestrel (progestin)
  • Thickens cervical mucus
  • Alters endometrial lining
  • May suppress ovulation in some women

5-7 years
  • Lighter menstrual periods
  • Reduced menstrual cramps
  • Protection against endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)?

options.label: A
options.text: If a single OCP pill is missed, a new pack must be started immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: OCPs increase the risk of ovarian and endometrial cancers.

options.label: C
options.text: Missing three consecutive OCP pills during the first week necessitates using an additional contraceptive method for at least 7 days.

options.label: D
options.text: OCPs can be taken at any time of day without impacting their effectiveness.

questions.correct_answer: C. Missing three consecutive OCP pills during the first week necessitates using an additional contraceptive method for at least 7 days.

questions.text: A 35 y/o woman suffering from migraine without aura for the past 2 years wants to start on OCPs. She is also a known smoker for the past 12 years. Which adverse effect is the highest risk and likely to contraindicate its use?
Which of the following is NOT an action of the combined oral contraceptive pill?

options.label: A
options.text: Suppression of ovulation through inhibition of pituitary hormones.

options.label: B
options.text: Thickening of cervical mucus to block sperm entry.

options.label: C
options.text: Induction of atrophic changes in the endometrium to prevent implantation.

options.label: D
options.text: Kills the sperm in the cervix.

questions.correct_answer: D. Kills the sperm in the cervix.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents to your clinic for contraception advice. She has a past h/o deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago. What is this patient's Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) category for combined oral contraceptives?
questions.explanation:
MEC Categories for Contraceptive Eligibility

MEC 1

A condition for which there is no restriction for the use of the contraceptive method. (C)

MEC 2

A condition where the advantages of using the method generally outweigh the theoretical or proven risks. (D)

MEC 3

A condition where the theoretical or proven risks usually outweigh the advantages of using the method. (A)

MEC 4

A condition that represents an unacceptable health risk if the contraceptive method is used.

questions.text: A woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea presents with excessive vomiting and slight bleeding from the vagina. On USG snow storm appearance is seen in the uterus. Molar evacuation is performed and she is asked to avoid pregnancy for 6 months. She can use all of the following contraceptive devices except?
questions.explanation:
Situation

Contraceptives used

Contraceptives avoided

Molar Pregnancy
  • OCP (Contraceptive of choice)
  • POP
  • DMPA
  • Condom

IUCD (Risk of uterine perforation)

Heart disease

IUCD
  • OCP
  • POP

(Both can cause water retention)

Uncontrolled Diabetes

Barriers with spermicidal agents

OCP (Both estrogen and sugar are metabolized by liver, increased sugar levels can interfere with contraception)

Newly married couple

OCP

  

Postnatal/lactation
  • POP (till 6 wks)
  • IUCD (after 6 wks)

OCP (Estrogen component can cause lactational failure)

questions.text: Identify the following contraceptive device:
questions.explanation:
Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Cheap
  • Can be used repeatedly for a long time
  • Reduces PID/STIs to some extent
  • Risk of vaginal irritation, abrasion and urinary tract infection are there
  • Requires help of a doctor or paramedical person to measure the size required
  • Not suitable in case of uterine prolapse.

Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Cost effective.
  • No side effects.
  • Easy to carry, simple to use and disposable
  • Protection against PID/STIs.
  • Reduces the incidence of tubal infertility and ectopic pregnancy.
  • May accidentally break or slip off during coitus
  • Inadequate sexual pleasure
  • Allergic reaction (latex)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about injectable progesterone? DMPA- Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate NET-EN- norethisterone enanthate

options.label: A
options.text: DMPA is administered i.m. every 2 months.

options.label: B
options.text: NET-EN is administered i.m. every 3 months.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be safely used in lactating women. .

options.label: D
options.text: They are associated with an increased risk of thromboembolism compared to cOCPs.

questions.correct_answer: C. They can be safely used in lactating women. .

questions.text: Match the type of contraceptive implant with its description: Contraceptive Implant Description a. Implanon i. Consists of a single closed capsule with etonogestrel and is effective for up to 3 years. b. Nexplanon ii. Consists of two rods, each containing levonorgestrel, providing contraception for up to 5 years. c. Jadelle iii. Single rod implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years. d. Norplant iv. Consists of six small, flexible capsules containing levonorgestrel which is implanted under the skin of the upper arm.
questions.explanation:
Implanon

Nexplanon

Jadelle

Norplant

Single rod implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years.

Consists of a single closed capsule with etonogestrel and is effective for up to 3 years.

 

Consists of two rods, each containing levonorgestrel, providing contraception for up to 5 years.

 





 

Consists of six small,flexible capsules containing levonorgestrel which is implanted under the skin of upper arm.
  • Fewer adverse effects reported
  • Similar to Implanon
  • Fewer adverse effects compared to Norplant
  • Higher incidence of irregular bleeding
  • Difficulty due to multiple rods
  • Straightforward insertion and removal
  • Preloaded applicator for easier insertion and removal
  • Easier insertion and removal compared to Norplant
  • Complicated insertion and removal due to multiple rods

questions.text: Which compound is the active ingredient in Saheli tablets, a non-hormonal oral contraceptive?
Which of the following statements about the mini-pill (progestin-only pill, POP) is true regarding its use in lactating women?

options.label: A
options.text: Early return of fertility once discontinued

options.label: B
options.text: It is the contraception of choice in breastfeeding women

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with a higher risk of blood clots compared to combined oral contraceptives

questions.correct_answer: B. It is the contraception of choice in breastfeeding women

Dose

Minipill [Levonorgestrel]

questions.text: Which of the following options represents a type of oral contraceptive formulation used for birth control?
Which of these conditions or characteristics would make drospirenone-containing combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) potentially inappropriate for use?
Which of the following women should seek alternative contraception methods due to absolute contraindications for combined oral contraceptive pills?

options.label: B
options.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines without aura

options.label: C
options.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer

options.label: D
options.text: A 25-year-old woman with well-managed type1 diabetes

questions.correct_answer: C. A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer
questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications of Combined Oral Contraceptives Pills (COCs)

Condition

Remarks

Pregnancy
  • COCs are strictly prohibited during pregnancy.

Circulatory Diseases (Past or Present)
  • Women who have a history of arterial or venous thrombosis, severe hypertension, stroke, or heart disease (valvular or ischemic) should avoid combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs).
  • The estrogen component in COCs can raise the risk of deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
  • This is because estrogen stimulates the liver to produce fibrinogen and clotting factors, which can contribute to clot formation.

Liver Diseases
  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) should not be used by women with active liver disease, jaundice, liver adenoma, or liver carcinoma.
  • The estrogen in COCs can increase the synthesis of hepatic angiotensinogen, which may contribute to hypertension.

Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding
  • COC use is not recommended for women with undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding.

Breast Cancer (Current or Past)
  • Women with known or suspected breast cancer should not use COCs.

Major Surgery or Prolonged Immobilisation
  • COCs are contraindicated in women who have recently undergone major surgery or experienced prolonged immobilization due to the increased risk of postoperative VTE.

Estrogen-Dependent Neoplasms
  • Women with known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasms should avoid using COCs.

Smoking and Age
  • COCs are not recommended for women older than 35 who smoke.

Diabetes with Vascular Complications
  • Women with diabetes and vascular complications should not use COCs.

Migraines with Focal Neurologic Symptoms
  • COCs should be avoided by women experiencing migraines with focal neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for insertion of an Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD)?
questions.correct_answer: A. Sexually transmitted infections within 6 months.
questions.explanation:
Contraindications for insertion of IUCD
  • Pregnancy.
  • Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding.
  • Sexually transmitted infections:current or within 3months.
  • Severe dysmenorrhea.
  • Uterine or cervical neoplasia.
  • Trophoblastic disease.
  • Significant immunosuppression.
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Wilson’s disease.
  • Copper allergy.
  • Current breast cancer.
  • Severe arterial disease.

questions.text: Which of the following natural contraception methods requires the combined use of tracking basal body temperature, monitoring cervical mucus, and recording menstrual cycle lengths to identify the fertile window?

A 28-year-old female G2P1 presents to the clinic at 7 weeks gestation by LMP. She reports using an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for contraception. On examination, the IUCD strings are not visualized on the speculum exam. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Visible Strings:

Gently remove the IUCD by pulling on the strings after explaining the possible risks to the mother.

No Strings Visible

Continue the pregnancy with monitoring.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, lower abdominal pain, and abnormal vaginal discharge for the past week. She had an IUCD inserted two months ago. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and cervical motion tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Incidence of pregnancy is less for women with IUCD compared to normal women

Therefore Incidence of ectopic pregnancy is also less in IUCD users

But if a woman with IUCD is pregnant—--> Rule out ectopic pregnancy

SIDE EFFECTS OF IUCD

IMMEDIATE

REMOTE
  • Cramp-like pain
  • Abnormal menstrual bleeding(most common)
  • Syncopal attack
  • Pain (2nd most common)
  • Partial or complete perforation
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Spontaneous expulsion
  • Perforation of the uterus

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman inquiring about long-acting contraception options is considering an IUCD. What is the primary mechanism of action of the instrument in the image?
A 25-year-old newly married woman wants effective contraception with a minimum failure rate. Which contraceptive method would be the most suitable for her considering both efficacy and ease of use?

A 25 y/o woman visits her gynecologist seeking advice on starting oral OCP. She prefers a low-dose option with both progestogen and estrogen components. What is the correct dose of the prescribed OCP?
questions.correct_answer: B. LNG 0.15 mg and EE 30 mcg

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Copper T 380A intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD)?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a second-generation IUCD that releases copper ions, impairing sperm motility and viability.

options.label: B
options.text: It releases levonorgestrel to suppress ovulation and thin the endometrium.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a first-generation IUCD made of inert plastic without any medication.

options.label: D
options.text: It is effective for only 5 years and mainly used for women with heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a second-generation IUCD that releases copper ions, impairing sperm motility and viability.
